response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "This measure proposes to establish a temporary three-year Women’s Court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits. [CHUNK_4] As amended, the bill establishes a temporary three-year women's court pilot program within the Second and Fifth Circuits and requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_19] The intent of the program is to implement trauma informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration and reducing recidivism. [CHUNK_4]",
  "appropriations": "The measure appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services. [CHUNK_40] An appropriation is inserted for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions. [CHUNK_47] The Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_) to the Department of Health. [CHUNK_48]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The Department of Health's requested budget of $801,802 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [CHUNK_7] The Third Circuit's proposal for a Kona Women’s Court pilot project is developed under the pre-existing drug court program, using the established structures of drug court as its “backbone”. [CHUNK_23] The proposal for West Hawai'i is based on the need to develop critical resources and services due to the severe shortage of community-based treatment options on Hawaiʻi Island. [CHUNK_22]",
  "agency_impact": "This measure requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_45] The Judiciary is also required to submit annual reports on the pilot program throughout its duration. [CHUNK_41] The Department of Health requests funding for this measure to expand services, including staff support, and proposes a budget based on staffing needs for a clinical psychologist, social worker, and social services assistant in each circuit. [CHUNK_2] [CHUNK_8]",
  "economic_impact": "The program has the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [CHUNK_5] Supportive services are far less costly than incarceration when a person reoffends. [CHUNK_0] By providing services like counseling, housing assistance, and job training, the program helps justice involved women have the support and tools they need to become productive members of society. [CHUNK_0]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure builds upon the successful Women’s Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit, Mohala Wahine, which was established by Act 243, SLH 2022. [CHUNK_5] The bill was amended to delete language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [CHUNK_45] It instead requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_45]",
  "revenue_sources": "The measure appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment and services. [CHUNK_40] It also inserts an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_47] The funding source is not specified beyond legislative appropriation. [CHUNK_11]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The Judiciary proposed a two-year pilot program for Kona with a total cost of $1,071,900 (HB727_HD1). [CHUNK_36] The budget for year one is $514,900 (HB727_HD1) and for year two is $557,000 (HB727_HD1). [CHUNK_36] This budget includes one full-time equivalent position for a Women's Mental Health Professional at $175,000 (HB727_HD1) per year, one FTE for a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor at $85,000 (HB727_HD1) per year, and one FTE for a Peer Specialist at $80,000 (HB727_HD1) per year. [CHUNK_36] Contracted services include Womens Behavioral Health Beds at $100,000 (HB727_HD1) annually and a Cultural Practitioner at $30,000 (HB727_HD1) annually. [CHUNK_36] Training is budgeted at $5,000 (HB727_HD1) in year one and $42,000 (HB727_HD1) in year two. [CHUNK_36] Technology costs are budgeted at $4,900 (HB727_HD1) in the first year. [CHUNK_36] The Department of Health requests a recurring budget of $801,802 (HB727_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) for the pilot program in the other circuits. [CHUNK_7] The pilot program established by this measure sunsets on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_11]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents do not specify any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from this measure. [CHUNK_18] The measure focuses on appropriations for program expenditures. [CHUNK_11] No new fees, fines, or other revenue streams are created by the bill. [CHUNK_11]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The Judiciary is appropriated funds for equipment. [CHUNK_40] The Judiciary's proposal for the Kona pilot includes a technology budget of $4,900 (HB727_HD1). [CHUNK_36] This funding is for a computer workstation, a computer and printer for the Kona Probation Supervisor, a cellphone, and a laptop. [CHUNK_36]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The women's court pilot program sunsets on 6/30/2028. [CHUNK_11] The Judiciary's proposal for the Kona pilot states that if the program is successful, the ultimate goal would be to expand the program to Hilo and make it permanent. [CHUNK_36] Making the program permanent would create ongoing fiscal obligations for staffing and services beyond the pilot period. [CHUNK_36]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The scope of the pilot program has changed significantly. [CHUNK_19] The current measure establishes a pilot in the Second and Fifth Circuits and requires a study for the Third Circuit, whereas the previous note described a pilot program established only in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_19] The appropriations are substantially different; the previous note detailed specific funding of $514,900 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_) and $557,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_) for the Judiciary's Kona pilot and deleted Department of Health (DOH) funding. [CHUNK_47] The current version provides an unspecified appropriation to the Judiciary while inserting an appropriation for the DOH, with a recommended amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_). [CHUNK_48] Consequently, the agency impact has shifted from two temporary positions in the Judiciary to an unspecified number, and new positions established within the DOH. [CHUNK_46] [CHUNK_47]"
}

FINK, M.D., M.G.A, M.P.H DIRECTOR OF HEALTH KA LUNA HOʻOKELE STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH KA ʻOIHANA OLAKINO P. O. Box 3378 Honolulu, HI 96801-3378 doh.testimony@doh.hawaii.gov Testimony in SUPPORT of HB727 RELATING TO THE

96801-3378 doh.testimony@doh.hawaii.gov Testimony in SUPPORT of HB727 RELATING TO THE WOMEN’S COURT REPRESENTATIVE DAVID A. TARNAS, CHAIR HOUSE COMMITTEE ON JUDICIARY AND HAWAIIAN AFFAIRS Hearing Date and Time: January 30, 2025, 2:00 p.m. Location: Room 325 & Videoconference. Fiscal Implications: The Department of Health (“Department”) requests funding for this 1

The Department of Health (“Department”) requests funding for this 1 measure be considered as a vehicle to expand services, including staff support, provided it does 2 not supplant the requests outlined in the Governor's executive budget request. 3 Department Position: The Department supports this measure and offers comments. 4 Department

The Department supports this measure and offers comments. 4 Department Testimony: The Adult Mental Health Division provides the following testimony on 5 behalf of the Department. 6 The Department supports this measure which proposes to establish a three-year 7 Women’s Court pilot program in the circuit court of the second,

Court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits. The 8 intent of the program is to implement trauma informed and evidence-based practices, employ 9 gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to 10 women in the court system with the goal of diverting

women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, 11 supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. 12 Mohala Wahine, which was established in the first circuit by Act 243, SLH 2022, has 13 been operational since January 2023. In 2024, through our collaborative

been operational since January 2023. In 2024, through our collaborative partnership with the 14 Judiciary, the Department conducted 33 mental health screenings and 24 psychological 15 assessments of participants for the program. The services offered by the program are 16 HB727 Page 2 of 2 comprehensive and provide an opportunity

HB727 Page 2 of 2 comprehensive and provide an opportunity for participants to achieve meaningful and lasting 1 recovery. 2 Offered Amendments: The Department requests a budget of $801,802, which is based on the 3 Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot 4 project of

operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot 4 project of the First Circuit. Each circuit would require the following: 5 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist [$145,000] to conduct psychological assessments 6 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV [$76,788] to conduct screenings 7 1.0 FTE Social Services Assistant V [$45,216] to

screenings 7 1.0 FTE Social Services Assistant V [$45,216] to provide peer support 8 Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this measure. 9 The Judiciary, State of Hawai‘i Testimony to the Thirty-Third Legislature, 2025 Regular Session House Committee on Judiciary and Hawaiian Affairs Representative David A. Tarnas, Chair

on Judiciary and Hawaiian Affairs Representative David A. Tarnas, Chair Representative Mahina Poepoe, Vice Chair Thursday, January 30, 2025, 2:00 p.m. State Capitol, Conference Room 325 & Videoconference by Robert D. S. Kim Chief Court Administrator Third Circuit Court Bill No. and Title: House Bill No. 727, Relating to Women’s

No. and Title: House Bill No. 727, Relating to Women’s Court. Purpose: Establishes a temporary three-year woman's court pilot program within the second, third, and fifth circuits. Establishes temporary positions. Requires a report. Appropriates funds. Sunsets 6/30/2028. Judiciary's Position: The Judiciary supports the intent of this measure and proposes amendments

Judiciary supports the intent of this measure and proposes amendments and modifications based on unique circumstances found on the Big Island, and the structure of the state courts in the Third Circuit. The Judiciary looks forward to opportunities to build upon the successful Women’s Court Pilot Program in the First

upon the successful Women’s Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit that this measure represents. To be successful, Women’s Court requires sufficient funding and positions, and a good prospect of recruiting qualified staff for those positions. To be an effective use of resources, Women’s Court also requires a critical mass

use of resources, Women’s Court also requires a critical mass of female probationers who may be eligible for the program. Accordingly, the design of a program tailored to the unique needs of the population and with robust therapeutic rehabilitative components for women will be different on the neighbor islands than

for women will be different on the neighbor islands than it has been on O‘ahu. The circuit courts in the Third Circuit are structured very differently than that of the First Circuit. Circuit court judges are responsible for hearing all cases, such as criminal, civil, agency House Bill No. 727,

cases, such as criminal, civil, agency House Bill No. 727, Relating to Women’s Court House Committee Judiciary and Hawaiian Affairs Thursday, January 30, 2025 Page 2 appeals, environmental cases and more. The Big Island Drug Court (BIDC) is stationed in both Hilo and Kona. BIDC also oversees the Veteran’s Treatment

both Hilo and Kona. BIDC also oversees the Veteran’s Treatment Court and the Juvenile Treatment Court. The circuit courts on the Big Island are unable to manage another stand-alone specialty treatment court as represented by the template of the successful First Circuit program. However, creating a Women’s Division

The Judiciary, State of Hawai‘i Testimony to the Thirty-Third Legislature, 2025 Regular Session Senate Committee on Judiciary Senator Karl Rhoads, Chair Senator Mike Gabbard, Vice Chair Wednesday, March 19, 2025, 9:45 a.m. State Capitol, Conference Room 016 by Robert D. S. Kim Chief Court Administrator Third Circuit Court Bill No.

S. Kim Chief Court Administrator Third Circuit Court Bill No. and Title: House Bill No. 727, H.D. 1, Relating to the Women’s Court. Purpose: Establishes a temporary three-year women's court pilot program within the Second and Fifth Circuits. Requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court

Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. Requires reports. Establishes temporary positions. Appropriates funds. Effective 7/1/3000. Sunsets 6/30/2028. (HD1) Third Circuit's Position: The Third Circuit supports the intent

(HD1) Third Circuit's Position: The Third Circuit supports the intent of this measure to expand the women’s court pilot project. However, the Third Circuit proposes amendments and modifications to this bill so that the pilot project can be implemented in the Third Circuit and can be successful in light of

the Third Circuit and can be successful in light of the lack of availability of community-based mental health services on the neighbor islands. The Third Circuit respectfully requests the bill to be amended to reflect a two-year program for the Big Island. Attached to this testimony is a detailed proposal

Big Island. Attached to this testimony is a detailed proposal for the establishment of a two-year Women’s Court pilot project in the Kona Division of the Third Circuit Court. In order to successfully implement this Kona Women’s Court (“KWC”) program, this bill would need to be modified to: (1) establish

this bill would need to be modified to: (1) establish a two-year women’s court pilot project in the Circuit Court of the Third Circuit; (2) provide for sufficient funding and staff to operate the program in Kona for the duration of the two-year pilot project; (3) permit the program to

of the two-year pilot project; (3) permit the program to operate House Bill No. 727, H.D. 1, Relating to the Women’s Court Senate Committee on Judiciary Wednesday, March 19, 2025 Page 2 as a separate program under the supervision of Big Island Drug Court (“BIDC”); (4) establish direct-provider positions and

Big Island Drug Court (“BIDC”); (4) establish direct-provider positions and funding for direct services, which are otherwise unavailable on the Big Island; and (5) delete the provisions of the bill requiring the Second and Fifth Circuits to establish a three-year women’s court pilot project. The Circuit Courts in the Third

women’s court pilot project. The Circuit Courts in the Third Circuit are structured very differently than those of the First Circuit. Due to the large size of Hawaiʻi Island, the Third Circuit has two main courthouses housing Circuit Courts—one in Hilo and one in Kona. These courthouses are located 100

Hilo and one in Kona. These courthouses are located 100 miles apart. The Circuit Courts in the Third Circuit are also dual-docket courts, meaning Circuit Court judges are responsible for hearing all case types, including criminal, civil, agency appeals, environmental cases, and more. Due to these practical restrictions on the

cases, and more. Due to these practical restrictions on the courts’ calendar and the geography of the island, it has never been practical in the Third Circuit to have standalone specialty courts, as has been done successfully in the First Circuit. Nevertheless, the Third Circuit has a history of implementing

Circuit. Nevertheless, the Third Circuit has a history of implementing successful treatment court programs, and the Judiciary now looks forward to the opportunity to build upon this history and establish a successful women’s court program in Kona. Our proposal calls for the KWC program to be supervised by the Kona

for the KWC program to be supervised by the Kona Division of BIDC. This administrative structure is similar to the other successful treatment court programs currently offered in the Third Circuit. Due to the success of the BIDC program, Veterans’ Treatment Court and Juvenile Treatment Court programs have also been

Treatment Court and Juvenile Treatment Court programs have also been implemented in the Third Circuit. These programs are not standalone courts, but rather operate as separate divisions of BIDC with their own programming, eligibility requirements, and procedures. The proposed KWC program would be the latest addition to these successful specialty

program would be the latest addition to these successful specialty court programs. Accordingly, by situating KWC under the supervision of BIDC with our other treatment court programs, the existing BIDC structure and staff can be leveraged at the outset of the program, allowing us to supplement existing services with the

the program, allowing us to supplement existing services with the additional resources to be provided by this bill. This structure will maximize existing resources and allow the program to focus its efforts on developing the programming and services that are at the heart of this pilot project. Additionally, to be

at the heart of this pilot project. Additionally, to be an effective use of resources, the KWC program will require a critical mass of female probationers in West Hawaiʻi who may be eligible for the program. The highest-risk justice-involved women in the Third Circuit (“Priority 1 participants”) are already participating

in the Third Circuit (“Priority 1 participants”) are already participating in the BIDC program. Thus, our proposal calls for all fourteen (14) of the women currently participating in the Kona BIDC program to be screened for eligibility for the KWC program. During the cour

HSCR624 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 624 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled:

Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary

in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. Specifically, this measure: (1) Requires the pilot program to implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism; (2) Appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services;

for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions for the pilot program; and (3) Requires the Judiciary to submit annual reports on the pilot program throughout its duration. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of

testimony in support of this measure from the Department of Health; Judiciary; Office of the Public Defender; Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Kaua ʻ i; Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui; Community Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women

Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women Voters of Hawaii; American Civil Liberties Union of Hawai ʻ i; and two individuals. Your Committee finds that research has shown that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women

women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women offenders are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization. This measure seeks to address these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. Your Committee

these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and instead requiring the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to

Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit; (2) Changing the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount; (3) Inserting an appropriation for the Department of

unspecified amount; (3) Inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions; (4) Changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion; and (5) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. Your

amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance, should it deliberate on this measure, to consider establishing seven temporary positions in the Judiciary and an appropriation amount of $801,802 to the Department of Health, including: (1) $145,000 for one full-time equivalent

Department of Health, including: (1) $145,000 for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary clinical psychologist position; (2) $76,788 for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary social worker/human services professional IV position; and (3) $45,216 for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary social services assistant V position, to be placed in

temporary social services assistant V position, to be placed in the Department of Health. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B.

is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 727, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Finance. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the
Finance. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, ____________________________ DAVID A. TARNAS, Chair

No. and Title: House Bill No. 727, Relating to Women’s Court. Purpose: Establishes a temporary three-year woman's court pilot program within the second, third, and fifth circuits. Establishes temporary positions. Requires a report. Appropriates funds. Sunsets 6/30/2028. Judiciary's Position: The Judiciary supports the intent of this measure and proposes amendments

Judiciary supports the intent of this measure and proposes amendments and modifications based on unique circumstances found on the Big Island, and the structure of the state courts in the Third Circuit. The Judiciary looks forward to opportunities to build upon the successful Women’s Court Pilot Program in the First

upon the successful Women’s Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit that this measure represents. To be successful, Women’s Court requires sufficient funding and positions, and a good prospect of recruiting qualified staff for those positions. To be an effective use of resources, Women’s Court also requires a critical mass

use of resources, Women’s Court also requires a critical mass of female probationers who may be eligible for the program. Accordingly, the design of a program tailored to the unique needs of the population and with robust therapeutic rehabilitative components for women will be different on the neighbor islands than

for women will be different on the neighbor islands than it has been on O‘ahu. The circuit courts in the Third Circuit are structured very differently than that of the First Circuit. Circuit court judges are responsible for hearing all cases, such as criminal, civil, agency House Bill No. 727,

cases, such as criminal, civil, agency House Bill No. 727, Relating to Women’s Court House Committee Judiciary and Hawaiian Affairs Thursday, January 30, 2025 Page 2 appeals, environmental cases and more. The Big Island Drug Court (BIDC) is stationed in both Hilo and Kona. BIDC also oversees the Veteran’s Treatment

both Hilo and Kona. BIDC also oversees the Veteran’s Treatment Court and the Juvenile Treatment Court. The circuit courts on the Big Island are unable to manage another stand-alone specialty treatment court as represented by the template of the successful First Circuit program. However, creating a Women’s Division

(HD1) Third Circuit's Position: The Third Circuit supports the intent of this measure to expand the women’s court pilot project. the Third Circuit and can be successful in light of the lack of availability of community-based mental health services on the neighbor islands. Big Island. Attached to this testimony is a detailed proposal for the establishment of a two-year Women’s Court pilot project in the Kona Division of the Third Circuit Court. this bill would need to be modified to: (1) establish a two-year women’s court pilot project in the Circuit Court of the Third Circuit; (2) provide for sufficient funding and staff to operate the program in Kona for the duration of the two-year pilot project; (3) permit the program to

women’s court pilot project. The Circuit Courts in the Third Circuit are structured very differently than those of the First Circuit. Due to the large size of Hawaiʻi Island, the Third Circuit has two main courthouses housing Circuit Courts—one in Hilo and one in Kona. These courthouses are located 100

Hilo and one in Kona. These courthouses are located 100 miles apart. The Circuit Courts in the Third Circuit are also dual-docket courts, meaning Circuit Court judges are responsible for hearing all case types, including criminal, civil, agency appeals, environmental cases, and more. cases, and more. Due to these practical restrictions on the courts’ calendar and the geography of the island, it has never been practical in the Third Circuit to have standalone specialty courts, as has been done successfully in the First Circuit. Circuit. Nevertheless, the Third Circuit has a history of implementing successful treatment court programs, and the Judiciary now looks forward to the opportunity to build upon this history and establish a successful women’s court program in Kona. Our proposal calls for the KWC program to be supervised by the Kona

for the KWC program to be supervised by the Kona Division of BIDC. This administrative structure is similar to the other successful treatment court programs currently offered in the Third Circuit. Due to the success of the BIDC program, Veterans’ Treatment Court and Juvenile Treatment Court programs have also been

Treatment Court and Juvenile Treatment Court programs have also been implemented in the Third Circuit. These programs are not standalone courts, but rather operate as separate divisions of BIDC with their own programming, eligibility requirements, and procedures. The proposed KWC program would be the latest addition to these successful specialty

program would be the latest addition to these successful specialty court programs. Accordingly, by situating KWC under the supervision of BIDC with our other treatment court programs, the existing BIDC structure and staff can be leveraged at the outset of the program, allowing us to supplement existing services with the

the program, allowing us to supplement existing services with the additional resources to be provided by this bill. at the heart of this pilot project. HSCR624 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 624 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled:

Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 727 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary

in the Second, Third, and Fifth Circuits of the Judiciary to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. Specifically, this measure: (1) Requires the pilot program to implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism; (2) Appropriates funds to the Judiciary for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services;

for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions for the pilot program; and (3) Requires the Judiciary to submit annual reports on the pilot program throughout its duration. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of

testimony in support of this measure from the Department of Health; Judiciary; Office of the Public Defender; Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Kaua ʻ i; Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui; Community Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women

Alliance on Prisons; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; League of Women Voters of Hawaii; American Civil Liberties Union of Hawai ʻ i; and two individuals. Your Committee finds that research has shown that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women

women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. Women offenders are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization. This measure seeks to address these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. Your Committee

these barriers and improve outcomes for women offenders. Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to study and submit a report on establishing a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit; (2) Changing the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount; (3) Inserting an appropriation for the Department of

unspecified amount; (3) Inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program, including the establishment of positions; (4) Changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion; and (5) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. temporary social services assistant V position, to be placed in the Department of Health. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B.

is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 727, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Finance. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the
